posts.name: chase  steenhoven
posts.cooked: I've been working on a ESP32-based Kiwi-Drive robot for nearly a year now. I’d like to utilize the DriverStation app by proxy since the open-source data related to NI DriverStation is scarce and the ESP32’s processing capabilities are limited.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: There was a prior reverse engineering effort that examined the driverstation protocol. The ESP possesses sufficient processing power for basic robotics operations. I would estimate its processing power to be approximately 25% of a Rio's, which has ample power to support a robot.

posts.name: mshafer1
posts.cooked:
Sure, here's the cleaned-up version of your text:

25% may be generous. Worthwhile? Likely not.

What functionality are you wanting?

Read USB joysticks and send scaled values to the device?

posts.name: chase  steenhoven
posts.cooked: Mostly, I just want this for novel reasons. I already have it operating via Bluetooth directly connected to my PS5 controller. I might add a dedicated ESP32 running a web server and create a DS (Driver Station) website. ESPNow works very well for inter-ESP communications.

posts.name: mshafer1
posts.cooked: If this is mostly for a “coolness” factor, it would probably be a lot easier to build a similarly looking site (or even desktop app) that implements just the features you’re using. The Driver Station relies on a stack of technology that the rio has either baked in or included in the image or team code (mDNS, using particular ports both in TCP and UDP, reporting lots of data, polling for game mode every 20 mS, polling for joystick position every 20 mS but only in telep, to name a few).

posts.name: chase  steenhoven

posts.name: Evan Kruger
posts.cooked: MiniFRC uses ESP-32-based robots and controls them through pestol.ink, a dashboard for Bluetooth robot control accessible via mobile or desktop devices.
You can access the same simulation hooks utilized by the XRP and Romi kits when working with WPILIB, which natively supports the drive station functionality.

posts.name: TommyG
posts.cooked: Albeit this might not be what you're looking for, I recall working on a similar project a few years ago. I used an ESP32 for a small mecanum bot and wanted functionality akin to the FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) Driverstation, though it ended up being quite different. Instead, I developed a TCP-based driverstation entirely in VB.NET, designed to communicate with an ESP32. This open-source project allows users to connect a Xbox controller via USB. Though underdeveloped and not regularly updated, it provides a basic framework for such applications.
